note.title: A Quick Guide on How to Create Accessible Buttons in HTML

pageProps.body:
A Quick Guide on How to Create Accessible Buttons in HTML

https://hackernoon.com/a-quick-guide-on-how-to-create-accessible-buttons-in-html

Accessibility was always important, but lately, it has gained even more traction, and if you don‚Äôt know how to create accessible websites, you can‚Äôt really call yourself a good front-end developer.

That‚Äôs a bold statement, I know, but it‚Äôs true. Just deal with it.

Today we‚Äôll look at one of the most basic elements of any website: a button. How do I make it accessible? Without further ado, let‚Äôs just jump into it.

First and foremost, use a button tag. You might ask, why not a div for example?

Here you have a few reasons button tag is the better choice:

  1. It‚Äôs semantically correct. Semantic HTML is really important. It helps with code readability and also helps web crawlers better understand our website.
  2. It‚Äôs focusable and clickable by default. You don‚Äôt need to implement those behaviors (but if you use some CSS frameworks that reset styles for every element - remember to implement hover and focus states)
  3. It‚Äôs recognizable by screen readers. When you use any of the screen readers, it will announce the button tag as, well, a button.

Is that it? That would be great, wouldn‚Äôt it be? But no, the next thing we need to talk about is button content. Here we can go three ways:

  1. Text
  2. Icon + text
  3. Only Icon

Text Buttons

In this case, the best thing we can do is to just use the text that is self-explanatory. We don‚Äôt need to put any additional attributes to make this kind of button accessible. There can be occasions where you‚Äôd be tempted to use aria-label to ‚Äúoverwrite‚Äù the text on the button. I strongly recommend you not to do it - it is against one of the WCAG principles.

NOTE: You can check all the code that I use in this article here: Codepen

<html lang="en">
  <body>
    <button>This is a test button</button>

    <!-- incorrect -->
    <button aria-label="This is a different button">
      This is another button
    </button>
  </body>
</html>

Icon with Text Buttons

The second case - icon with text is also quite simple. We can actually use the same technique as for the simple text, but with one additional thing - we‚Äôll need to add aria-hidden=true attribute for the svg icon. This way, screen readers will ignore the icon and read only the text.

One thing also worth doing is to add focusable=false attribute as some of the old browsers focus on svg for some reason.

<button>
  <svg
    class="svg-icon"
    viewBox="0 0 20 20"
    aria-hidden="true"
    focusable="false"
  >
    <title>The icon</title>
    <path
      d="M9.719,17.073l-6.562-6.51c-0.27-0.268-0.504-0.567-0.696-0.888C1.385,7.89,1.67,5.613,3.155,4.14c0.864-0.856,2.012-1.329,3.233-1.329c1.924,0,3.115,1.12,3.612,1.752c0.499-0.634,1.689-1.752,3.612-1.752c1.221,0,2.369,0.472,3.233,1.329c1.484,1.473,1.771,3.75,0.693,5.537c-0.19,0.32-0.425,0.618-0.695,0.887l-6.562,6.51C10.125,17.229,9.875,17.229,9.719,17.073 M6.388,3.61C5.379,3.61,4.431,4,3.717,4.707C2.495,5.92,2.259,7.794,3.145,9.265c0.158,0.265,0.351,0.51,0.574,0.731L10,16.228l6.281-6.232c0.224-0.221,0.416-0.466,0.573-0.729c0.887-1.472,0.651-3.346-0.571-4.56C15.57,4,14.621,3.61,13.612,3.61c-1.43,0-2.639,0.786-3.268,1.863c-0.154,0.264-0.536,0.264-0.69,0C9.029,4.397,7.82,3.61,6.388,3.61"
    ></path>
  </svg>
  Button with icon
</button>

Icon Buttons

The third case - icon only button is also pretty straightforward. We can just use aria-label on the button tag, and the screen readers will ignore everything that‚Äôs inside the button (so, in this case, an icon). We don‚Äôt even need to add aria-hidden=true on the icon.

<button aria-label="Like">
  <svg class="svg-icon" viewBox="0 0 20 20" focusable="false" width="40px">
    <title>The icon</title>
    <path
      d="M9.719,17.073l-6.562-6.51c-0.27-0.268-0.504-0.567-0.696-0.888C1.385,7.89,1.67,5.613,3.155,4.14c0.864-0.856,2.012-1.329,3.233-1.329c1.924,0,3.115,1.12,3.612,1.752c0.499-0.634,1.689-1.752,3.612-1.752c1.221,0,2.369,0.472,3.233,1.329c1.484,1.473,1.771,3.75,0.693,5.537c-0.19,0.32-0.425,0.618-0.695,0.887l-6.562,6.51C10.125,17.229,9.875,17.229,9.719,17.073 M6.388,3.61C5.379,3.61,4.431,4,3.717,4.707C2.495,5.92,2.259,7.794,3.145,9.265c0.158,0.265,0.351,0.51,0.574,0.731L10,16.228l6.281-6.232c0.224-0.221,0.416-0.466,0.573-0.729c0.887-1.472,0.651-3.346-0.571-4.56C15.57,4,14.621,3.61,13.612,3.61c-1.43,0-2.639,0.786-3.268,1.863c-0.154,0.264-0.536,0.264-0.69,0C9.029,4.397,7.82,3.61,6.388,3.61"
    ></path>
  </svg>
</button>

This is definitely the simplest and most supported solution. But what are the alternatives?

The first one would be creating a sr-only or visuallyhidden class in your CSS and then using it to create an ‚Äúinvisible‚Äù label.

TailwindCSS defines sr-only class as follows:

.sr-only {
  **position: absolute;
  width: 1px;
  height: 1px;
  padding: 0;
  margin: -1px;
  overflow: hidden;
  clip: rect(0, 0, 0, 0);
  white-space: nowrap;
  border-width: 0;
}

When you have this class in place, you can then use it like this:

<button>
  <svg
    class="svg-icon"
    viewBox="0 0 20 20"
    aria-hidden="true"
    focusable="false"
    width="40px"
  >
    <title>The icon</title>
    <path
      d="M9.719,17.073l-6.562-6.51c-0.27-0.268-0.504-0.567-0.696-0.888C1.385,7.89,1.67,5.613,3.155,4.14c0.864-0.856,2.012-1.329,3.233-1.329c1.924,0,3.115,1.12,3.612,1.752c0.499-0.634,1.689-1.752,3.612-1.752c1.221,0,2.369,0.472,3.233,1.329c1.484,1.473,1.771,3.75,0.693,5.537c-0.19,0.32-0.425,0.618-0.695,0.887l-6.562,6.51C10.125,17.229,9.875,17.229,9.719,17.073 M6.388,3.61C5.379,3.61,4.431,4,3.717,4.707C2.495,5.92,2.259,7.794,3.145,9.265c0.158,0.265,0.351,0.51,0.574,0.731L10,16.228l6.281-6.232c0.224-0.221,0.416-0.466,0.573-0.729c0.887-1.472,0.651-3.346-0.571-4.56C15.57,4,14.621,3.61,13.612,3.61c-1.43,0-2.639,0.786-3.268,1.863c-0.154,0.264-0.536,0.264-0.69,0C9.029,4.397,7.82,3.61,6.388,3.61"
    ></path>
  </svg>
  <span class="sr-only">Like</span>
</button>

And as you can see and hear, it works as expected (I strongly recommend you to try focusing on the buttons with VoiceOver turned on - it really helps in understanding the things that we are doing here).

Another solution is a little bit more complicated. We need to use aria-labelledby on the button and then provide a hidden label inside. Be aware that even though the label will be hidden, labelledby attribute will still be able to access it.

It would look like this:

<button aria-labelledby="likeBtn">
  <svg
    class="svg-icon"
    viewBox="0 0 20 20"
    aria-hidden="true"
    focusable="false"
    width="40px"
  >
    <title>The icon</title>
    <path
      d="M9.719,17.073l-6.562-6.51c-0.27-0.268-0.504-0.567-0.696-0.888C1.385,7.89,1.67,5.613,3.155,4.14c0.864-0.856,2.012-1.329,3.233-1.329c1.924,0,3.115,1.12,3.612,1.752c0.499-0.634,1.689-1.752,3.612-1.752c1.221,0,2.369,0.472,3.233,1.329c1.484,1.473,1.771,3.75,0.693,5.537c-0.19,0.32-0.425,0.618-0.695,0.887l-6.562,6.51C10.125,17.229,9.875,17.229,9.719,17.073 M6.388,3.61C5.379,3.61,4.431,4,3.717,4.707C2.495,5.92,2.259,7.794,3.145,9.265c0.158,0.265,0.351,0.51,0.574,0.731L10,16.228l6.281-6.232c0.224-0.221,0.416-0.466,0.573-0.729c0.887-1.472,0.651-3.346-0.571-4.56C15.57,4,14.621,3.61,13.612,3.61c-1.43,0-2.639,0.786-3.268,1.863c-0.154,0.264-0.536,0.264-0.69,0C9.029,4.397,7.82,3.61,6.388,3.61"
    ></path>
  </svg>
  <span id="likeBtn" hidden> Like </span>
</button>

Setting the id on the span is important because that‚Äôs how we can access the label from the labelledby attribute.

All three solutions work the same. That‚Äôs why my favorite is just setting the aria-label, it is the simplest solution.

These were the most important accessibility adjustments you can make to ensure your buttons work well with screen readers. But what about people with visual impairments that do not use screen readers? Here we have two additional things to take care of, and we‚Äôll be all set.

Sizing

First, let‚Äôs talk about sizing. In the WCAG guidelines, there is a criterion 2.5.5 - Target Size. It‚Äôs described as follows:

The size of the target for pointer inputs is at least 44 by 44 CSS pixels.

There are a few exceptions, and you can see those on the screen now. They are not relevant in this specific case.

A11Y

So let‚Äôs ensure that our buttons are, in fact, big enough. I‚Äôm not a fan of using pixels; I‚Äôd much rather go with rems or ems. This will also help if the user changes his base font size - the button will still be sized properly.

button {
  min-height: 3rem;
  min-width: 3rem;
}

I used 3rem as usually the root font size is 16px, so 3rem gives us 48px. But if the user zooms in to, let‚Äôs say, 24px, the button will be larger.

Ok, with that out of the way - let‚Äôs handle the last thing I want to talk about today - contrast.

Contrast

WCAG guidelines say:

The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 - for AA success criterion, and 7:1 for AAA criterion.

The best tool to use here is the contrast checker by WebAIM https://webaim.org/resources/contrastchecker/

You can just put your button color there, and you‚Äôll get the text color and vice versa. A simple yet great tool. In the case of my examples, let‚Äôs say I wanted a green button.

Contrast Checker

As you can see, white text fails all of the criteria, but black should be OK. As you can see, while I‚Äôm scrolling through the colors, the contrast ratio changes, and also different criteria are passing.

With straight black, we get a contrast of over 10 to 1. So that‚Äôs going to work!

And that‚Äôs it! Those are the things that you can do to make your buttons accessible. I hope you like it. If you did, consider following me on Twitter, Dev.to, and LinkedIn. More front-end and accessibility-related content are on the way.
